thread.title: No. 13 South River routs Arundel to claim first county title since 2009
thread.title_full: No. 13 South River routs Arundel to claim first county title since 2009

author: Glenn Graham
title: No. 13 South River routs Arundel to claim first county title since 2009
text:
No. 13 South River routs Arundel to claim first county title since 2009 (#{text}) Glenn Graham Contact Reporter The Baltimore Sun Four different South River players scored after halftime and goalie John Flanagan recorded his 11th shutout. 
During the first half of Tuesday's regular-season finale at Arundel, the South River boys soccer team was doing many of the same good things it had done all year in putting itself in position to claim the Anne Arundel County championship. 
The No. 13 Seahawks were poised in the back, methodically building from the midfield and getting some scoring chances in the final third. 
The only thing missing were goals, but those were plentiful in the second half. 
South River (11-1-2) got goals from Alden Sullivan and Tomi Adelekan in the first five minutes after the break and tacked on two more to come away with a convincing, 4-0 win over the Wildcats to claim the program's first county championship since 2009. 
Just how dominant were the Seahawks in county play this season? 
In going 9-0-1, they recorded nine shutouts and outscored their opponents by a whopping 36-1 margin. 
"In my four years playing high school soccer, I've never been closer with a group of guys. These guys are great. I look at them more as brothers than teammates," said senior goalkeeper and captain John Flanagan, who made four saves to record his 11th shutout. Read the story 
The Seahawks did some minor tweaking at halftime to make sure to break through with goals in the second half. They attacked the Wildcats (8-4, 7-3) from out wider and sent balls in low to make the needed connections in front. 
Sullivan scored less than three minutes after the break, taking a feed from senior Ryan Klaus and finding the near post from 8 yards for the much-needed first goal. Adelekan then scored unassisted less than three minutes later to make it 2-0. 
"We were knocking on their doorstep the entire first half and I just knew once we got one to go in the back of the net, they would start pouring in," Flanagan said. "That's the way to end the season, that's what we deserved and it's a great way to win the county championship." 
Photos from Anne Arundel County high school sports events in October 2015. 
Eric Janowitz and Danny Peterson scored later — Klaus also picking up his second assist — to ice the victory for the Seahawks, who got strong performance in back from central defenders Nick Koziolek and Mason Reinhart. After a season-opening loss to Archbishop Spalding, the Seahawks go into the Class 4A East region playoffs on an 11-0-2 roll. 
"They've worked hard in the offseason, they understood what they needed to work on, they put a lot of work into this," South River coach Jeff Vincent said. "They're a tough group. They're resilient and they play really hard."
